hawk-like fact with the long beak don't exaggerate very much at that. But
somehow they have never captured the twinkle in his eye that is always there,
behind the strong leases of his glasses.
There is something symbolic about De Gasperi sitting in the center of the
chamber. His philosophy and his program have been of the democratic middle-of-
the-road. He has been by far the most effective enemy of the two extremes —
Togliatti and his Communists over on the left, and the frustrated political
heirs of Benito Mussolini on the far right*
Sometimes you can tell much about a political man by the source and
violence of the attacks against him. De Gasperi took on the Communists at the
height of their postwar power — and licked them when few thought he could.
They have never forgiven him. When the neo-Fascists began to come out at the
political woods, De Gasperi flayed them, too, and laid down the law to his
oarty* no deal of any kind with the MSI. So the neo-Faseists, too, can
hardly find words strong enough to us© against him.
There he sits in the center of the Chamber with prestige and stature
matched by none of the other 539* In recent months he has taken on one of his
toughest Jobs * that of holding together and reforging into an effective poli¬
tical instrument the sharply-divided, bickering forces of the Christian Demo¬
cratic party. The fate of the Italian democracy may hinge on how well De Gas¬
peri succeeds. One gets the feeling that Italy sooner or later will turn
again to this remarkable man for leadership of the government*
Resuming the clockwise tour of the Chamber you come next to the benches
occupied by the Liberals and the monarchists and, finally — at the far right
end — the benches of the neo-Fasclst Movimento socials Italiano, of which I
was speaking a moment ago.
The Liberal party, which traces its origin to the great Cavour, is now
reduced to 14 chamber seats. Like the other democratic parties it is divided
between a left and right wing. Its deputies generally support the so-called
*sound money* fiscal policies and measures for European unification. The
Monarchists scored substantial gains in the 1953 elections and now have 40
deputies, a bloc big enough for serious political trading
The Monarchists once struck an electoral alliance with the neo-Faseists,
but have found that they do better by themselves. They gained some stature
with the country when they supported the recent government of Premier Pella,
ostensibly without asking .any price. Many Italians doubt that the Monarchists
really are serious about wishing to bring back king Umberto XI and scrap the
republic.
The MSI, on the far right of the Chamber bank, has 29 seats as the result
of its improved showing last year. Perhaps it is not too surprising that this
noisy crowd often finds itself voting with the Communists at the other end of
the spectrum, particularly on problems of Italian foreign policy.
